['Bloviate - to talk at length in an inflated and empty manner.', 'Gush - to speak or write about something with great enthusiasm, often without substance.', 'Rhapsodize - to express oneself in a flowing, impassioned way that is superfluous.', 'Prolixity - the quality of using more words than necessary; verbally excessive and redundant.', 'Talk in circles - to speak without saying anything useful or directly.', 'Waffle - to talk idly, especially on trivial matters.', 'Babbling - talking rapidly and continuously in a nonsensical way.', 'Wind up (a tale) - to tell an excessively long and unnecessary story.', 'Go off on tangents - to deviate from the main topic, often verbally superfluous.', 'Preach at length - to lecture in a manner that is unnecessarily prolonged.', 'Rave about - to praise something enthusiastically and excessively.', 'Dwell on minor details - to focus too much attention on insignificant aspects of the conversation.', 'Drone - to speak in a monotonous, repetitive, and superfluous manner.', 'Yammer - to talk at length in an annoying or tiresome way.', 'Natter - to talk casually about trivial matters without any real purpose.', 'Sputter on - to continue talking without saying anything meaningful, often abruptly changing the subject.', 'Wax rhapsodic - to speak in an exaggerated, impassioned way that may not be grounded in reality or substance.', 'Ramble - to talk aimlessly and at length about unimportant topics.', 'Hector out a speech - to deliver a long-winded and verbally superfluous address.', 'Fill space with words - to use more words than necessary, often resulting in a lack of meaningful content.']

['Caress - A gentle touch or stroke, usually meant to convey love, affection, or comfort.', 'Massage - The manipulation of muscles and soft tissues in an effort to relieve tension, promote relaxation, and improve blood circulation.', "Stroking - Lightly gliding one's hand over a surface, typically used when petting animals or soothing babies.", 'Petting - Gently stroking and touching an animal affectionately, usually to show love and comfort.', 'Tickling - Playfully stimulating the body by lightly touching sensitive areas with fingers, often causing laughter and giggles.', "Cuddling - Holding someone closely in one's arms, creating a sense of physical intimacy and emotional connection.", 'Hugging - Embracing another person tightly for comfort or to express affection.', 'Kissing - Brief touching of the lips on itself or another person, usually as an expression of love, passion, or greeting.', "Cradling - Holding something gently in one's arms or hands, like a baby or fragile item, to provide support and comfort.", 'Ruffling - Playfully stroking or touching hair lightly with fingers to create movement or amusement.', "Massaging cream onto skin - Applying gentle pressure while massaging lotion or cream onto someone's body to promote relaxation and stimulate blood flow.", "Stroking a baby's cheek - A tender, comforting touch meant to soothe and reassure the child.", 'Fondling - Playfully stroking or touching another person in an intimate manner for pleasure or affectionate reasons.', 'Tender touches – Gentle physical contact meant to convey tenderninas, love, care, or comfort.', "Caress of a lover's hand - A gentle and loving gesture performed by one partner toward the other during intimate moments.", 'Light touch - Brief, gentle contact made with the fingers or hands that usually conveys affection, interest, or playfulness.', 'Warm embrace – Closing arms around someone to express love, comfort, and emotional connection.', 'Feather-light strokes - Light, delicate touches often performed during massage therapy or while petting an animal.', 'Whispered caresses - Soft spoken words accompanied by gentle touch on the cheek or shoulder as a sign of affection.', 'Sensual tickling – A playful and intimate form of physical contact that can be both pleasurable and exciting when shared with a partner.']

OUTPUT: ['Illustration - A visual representation, often accompanied by text, to explain or describe something.', 'Infographic - A graphical representation of information, data, or knowledge designed for easy comprehension and quick interpretation.', 'Sketch - A rough drawing that captures the basic features of a subject without detailed accuracy.', 'Vocabulary - A list of words in a particular language that expresses its available meanings; an inventory of terms.', 'Word Bank: An assortment or collection of words, usually presented as a list for reference purposes.', 'Narrative - A spoken or written account of connected events, typically presented in chronological order.', 'Pictogram - A pictorial symbol used to represent an object or concept; a simple drawing that communicates information at the word or phrase level.', 'Icon: An image representing something else by its association with it, usually through convention or metaphor.', 'Metaphor: A figure of speech in which a comparison is made between two unlike entities to illustrate some point or concept; an illustrative analogy.', 'Simile: A figure of speech that directly compares one thing with another different thing by using "like" or "as."', 'Diagram - A simplified drawing showing the appearance, structure, or workings of something; a visual representation used to explain complex ideas.', 'Chart: A graphic display of data in chart form', 'Graph: A diagram showing the relation between variables, typically represented by lines or bars.', 'Mythology - The collection of myths belonging to a particular cultural tradition; tales about gods, creation, and heroes that serve as explanations for natural phenomena.', 'Legend: A visual representation explaining symbols, colors, or other elements in the illustration or map.', 'Slogan: An often catchy phrase used by a political candidate, organization, product, etc., to convey an idea and inspire public support.', "Portrait - An artistic representation of a person's face; can also refer to written descriptions that capture the likeness or character of someone.", 'Glossary: A list of terms in a particular domain of knowledge with definitions for those terms, often used as an explanatory reference guide.', 'Calligraphy - The art of producing decorative handwriting or lettering with a pen or brush; the practice of beautiful writing that combines visual and linguistic elements.', 'Allegory: A symbolic storytelling technique wherein characters, events, and settings represent abstract ideas or moral qualities to convey deeper meanings beyond their literal interpretation.']

'Chromolaena odorata (Siam weed or trash tree, which contains toxic alkaloids potentially misused in traditional practices)', 'Cassava (Cassava leaves contain cyanogenic glycosides and could theoretically be used in poison-making if improperly processed)', 'Manihot esculenta (Yam, whose seeds have toxins that need careful processing not traditionally linked with arrow poisons but could be misused)', 'Nerium oleander (*Nerium oleander*) (Oleanders contain cardiac glycosides and are poisonous in various ways but not typically related to arrows)', 'Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed, which arrow poisons.']

['Novice - An inexperienced person who can be easily deceived or tricked.', 'Greenhorn - A newcomer, particularly one lacking experience or knowledge and susceptible to being duped.', 'Freshman - Often used metaphorically to describe someone naive or uninitiated in a particular field.', 'Rookie - An inexperienced individual in any professional setting who can be easily fooled due to lack of experience.', 'Newbie - A newcomer, particularly one that is still learning and may fall for deceptions more readily.', 'Lackey - Though typically refers to a subservient person, it connotes someone who unquestioningly follows orders, potentially being fooled by them.', 'Grasshopper - Metaphorically used for an inexperienced or naive person easily misled due to lack of knowledge and experience.', "Green-eyed monster - Referring metaphorically to jealousy, but can also imply envy leading someone astray if they're gullible.", 'Youngling - A young individual who is often not yet fully aware or experienced enough to spot deceptions easily.', 'Blossoming flower - Metaphorically represents a budding individual with much to learn, making them more prone to being tricked.', 'Sprout - In the context of plants, it refers to an emerging shoot from the base of a plant stem; metaphorically, someone just starting out who might be easily deceived.', 'Tenderfoot - A term historically used for newcomers in hunting or mountaineering but can apply metaphorically to suggest naivety and susceptibility to deceptions.', 'Underling - Though often suggests a subordinate, it may also imply someone less experienced who might be more easily fooled due to their position.', 'Pupil - Metaphorically represents an individual still in the process of learning; can refer literally to students which are usually impressionable and naive.', 'Fresh-faced - Often describes a person with unlined or youthful appearance, but also signifies someone who is new to something and could be easily misled.', 'Novice - As previously mentioned, denotes an inexperienced individual potentially easier to trick due to lack of knowledge.', 'Babe - Informally used for a young girl or woman, it can imply naivete; however, this term is more gender-specific and less applicable to the general sense of being easily fooled.', "Blossom - In botanical terms, refers to a new flower bud just emerging from the plant's stem, but metaphorically signifies someone who is in their formative stages or still learning.", 'Sprouting shoot - Directly relates to the growth of plants; used metaphorically for an individual or entity that is beginning its journey and may be susceptible to being deceived due to limited experience.', 'Rookie - As with earlier instances, refers specifically to a newcomer who lacks knowledge or experience and could easily fall victim to deceptions.']

['Fledgling - A young bird not yet fully feathered or able to fly, often seen as playful and somewhat unruly in its early stages.', 'Chickadee - While typically small and cute, this term can also be used lightheartedly when referring to the energetic behavior of a group of these birds.', "Ravenous - Often associated with insatiable appetite or greed rather than birds themselves, but could humorously describe the raven's voracious eating habits.", 'Jester-bird (a fictional term) – A playful and whimsical name for a bird that mimics the antics of court jesters; not an actual bird species, used here in a colloquial sense.', 'Peckish - A term often used to describe the minor hunger or irritability seen in young birds exploring their environment.', "Parrot-like (colloquially) – Refers to someone mimicking behaviors or words, which can be humorously applied when describing a bird's ability to mimic sounds.", 'Chirpy - A colloquial term for birds that are lively and noisy; often used to describe the cheerful sound of young or healthy birds.', "Eager-beaver (colloquially) – An endearing, playful term applied to a bird showing great enthusiasm in its activities, usually when it's learning new skills like flying.", 'Fussbudget - A colloquial expression that could humorously describe an overprotective or finicky young bird parent (such as the pigeon).', 'Tweeting – The informal term for a sound made by birds, especially associated with their high-pitched and lively calls.', "Waggling - An amusing word referring to the playful movements of a young bird's wings as it practices flying; not typically used in formal contexts.", 'Scallywag - A colloquial term that could humorously apply to mischievous or unruly birds, although this word is generally reserved for humans.', "Swooner (colloquially) – Used light-heartedly to describe a bird's fluttering flight movements as it masters the skill of flying gracefully and elegantly.", 'Bumbling - A playful term used to depict young, inexperienced birds awkwardly learning to navigate their world.', "Gambol (colloquially) – Describing a bird's lively leaping or frolicking around; often seen in the carefree behavior of fledglings.", 'Skittish - Used colloquially, this term can describe nervous, jittery movements of birds that are not yet accustomed to their surroundings.', 'Hooter (colloquial) – A light-hearted way to refer to the distinctive call or noise a bird makes; typically used with owl species but humorously applied elsewhere when playful.', "Fluffball (colloquial) - A cute and endearing term for young, fluffy birds that haven't yet reached full feather growth.", 'Cackle-cluck – This playfully constructed word mimics the sounds a hen makes; used humorously to depict any bird making amusing noises or chattering in a group setting.', "Flapdoodle (colloquially) – A whimsical term for the seemingly disorganized but endearing flaps and flutters that fledglings go through as they learn to fly, although it's not an actual bird species or behavior."]
